document_metadata.title: Error Tolerance Map - Which Errors Persist and Who Accepts the Risk

error_tolerance_map.data_domain: Deal profitability—CRM opportunity value vs actual margin reality
common_error_types: CRM opportunity value overstates deal profitability by 13-15 percentage points (Private Cloud -13% margin, Public Cloud -3% margin indicates systematic entry optimism)
Cost estimates at CRM entry incomplete or optimistic—delivery complexity, customization effort, operational overhead underestimated
Revenue assumptions invalid—pricing holds, customer doesn't request scope changes, renewal occurs at assumed rate
Profitability determination lagged—deal profitability known only after delivery execution, retrospective margin calculation months after booking
error_tolerance_map.tolerance_threshold: EXPLICIT THRESHOLD DISCOVERED Q4 2024: CEO tolerance ends when segment margins negative double-digits (-13% Private Cloud). Walk away policy Q4 2024 reactive recognition after prolonged tolerance (margin erosion visible Q1-Q3 2024 preceding policy). IMPLICIT THRESHOLD PRIOR: Tolerated indefinitely while aggregate corporate margins positive—segment-level losses masked in corporate aggregate allowing prolonged tolerance. Tolerance duration: Months-to-years per deal (CRM entry to profitability discovery lag), quarters-to-years enterprise-wide (margin erosion trending negative before intervention).
error_tolerance_map.who_accepts_the_risk: RISK DISTRIBUTED: Sales benefits from CRM optimism through compensation (bookings-based incentive Stage 4.4), externalizes margin risk to delivery and finance. Delivery discovers cost reality post-signature, absorbs margin erosion through under-resourcing or losses (authority over delivery execution, no authority over deal acceptance Stage 4.1). Finance absorbs aggregate margin deterioration, manages investor expectations through conservative external adjustment (but adjustment insufficient to prevent -13%/-3% segment performance). CEO ultimately forced to intervene reactively when erosion severe (walk away policy, sales refresh Q3 2024). Customers indirectly absorb risk through service quality degradation when deals under-resourced to preserve margin.
error_tolerance_map.business_or_regulatory_consequence: BUSINESS CONSEQUENCES MATERIAL: Revenue rejection (walk away policy rejects unprofitable deals/renewals reducing revenue), sales force instability (Q3 2024 refresh, talent turnover Stage 4.5), resource misallocation (hiring and capacity planning based on inflated pipeline value), margin compression threatening debt covenants ($1.3B debt Stage 5, negative cash flow from operations Q2 2024). REGULATORY CONSEQUENCES POTENTIAL: If CRM pipeline materially overstates viability and used for investor guidance, forecast accuracy questioned by investors/SEC. No regulatory action visible in evidence—but investor credibility risk material.
error_tolerance_map.touch_test_what_breaks_if_zero_tolerance: Zero tolerance = profitability validation required at CRM entry before opportunity accepted. BREAKS: (1) Sales cycle velocity—profitability validation requires delivery cost estimation, technical architecture review, operational overhead allocation before CRM entry, adds weeks-months to sales cycle. (2) Sales compensation—if opportunities rejected at entry for profitability, bookings volume declines threatening quota achievement, sales turnover accelerates. (3) Pipeline optics—CRM pipeline value declines materially if only profitable opportunities entered, investor/Board perception of growth potential damaged. (4) Delivery bandwidth—profitability validation requires delivery participation in pre-sales, diverts delivery resources from execution to estimation creating delivery bottleneck. (5) Deal flexibility—profitability validation at entry assumes static requirements, but customer scope changes post-signature common, pre-validation effort wasted. CEO walk away policy is PARTIAL zero tolerance (reactive filter post-booking) not FULL zero tolerance (proactive validation pre-entry)—full enforcement breaks sales model.
evidence_sources: Stage 5 margin by segment: Private Cloud -13%, Public Cloud -3%
Stage 7.2 deal value transformation CRM T1 13-15% overstatement

error_tolerance_map.data_domain: Customer identity and count—parallel customer definitions across CRM, billing, support
common_error_types: Customer count discrepancies—CRM accounts N ≠ billing active accounts M ≠ support engaged accounts K, no single authoritative count
Definitional inconsistency—'customer' means contractual relationship (CRM), revenue-generating (billing), operationally active (support), definitions not reconciled
Churn calculation ambiguity—churn rate depends on denominator choice (which customer count used), churn truth contested
Duplicate or inactive accounts—CRM retains accounts post-churn, billing retains accounts with $0 revenue, support retains accounts with zero tickets, inactive accounts inflate counts
error_tolerance_map.tolerance_threshold: TOLERANCE INDEFINITE: No reconciliation process visible, parallel customer counts coexist without resolution. No explicit threshold identified—discrepancies tolerated regardless of magnitude. IMPLICIT THRESHOLD: Tolerance continues while discrepancies don't trigger external audit finding or investor questioning. If auditor questions customer metrics or if churn calculation disputed in M&A diligence, tolerance may end—but no evidence of this occurring yet. Tolerance duration: Years (customer count definitions established with systems, no governance initiative to reconcile visible).
error_tolerance_map.who_accepts_the_risk: RISK ACCEPTED BY FINANCE FOR EXTERNAL REPORTING: Finance chooses which customer definition to report externally (likely billing active accounts for revenue alignment), accepts risk that definition differs from sales (CRM) or operations (support) view. Sales accepts risk of CRM count inflated by inactive accounts—higher account counts support territory sizing, quota setting, but mask true customer engagement. Support accepts risk of engagement count diverging from billing—ticket volume/SLA metrics calculated on engaged customer base not total customer base. CEO/Board accept risk of customer metrics contested—when customer count questioned internally (sales vs finance vs support), no authoritative answer, escalation yields definition choice not truth reconciliation.
error_tolerance_map.business_or_regulatory_consequence: BUSINESS CONSEQUENCES: Customer lifetime value miscalculated if customer count denominator wrong, churn rate understated or overstated depending on definition choice, resource allocation (support staffing, account management) misaligned with true customer engagement. Investor communications risk—if external customer count later discovered materially inaccurate (e.g., included inactive accounts), guidance credibility damaged. M&A diligence risk—acquirer recalculates customer metrics using different definition, discovers customer base smaller or churn higher than Rackspace-reported. REGULATORY CONSEQUENCES: Minimal direct regulatory risk (customer counts not SEC-mandated disclosure), but if customer metrics used in material guidance (revenue per customer, retention rates), inaccuracy could trigger investor relations issues.
error_tolerance_map.touch_test_what_breaks_if_zero_tolerance: Zero tolerance = single authoritative customer definition enforced enterprise-wide, CRM = billing = support counts reconciled continuously. BREAKS: (1) System architecture—CRM, billing, support systems not integrated, reconciliation requires manual cross-system data quality process, ongoing maintenance resource-intensive. (2) Definitional consensus—functions cannot agree on single definition (sales wants contractual for pipeline, finance wants billing for revenue alignment, support wants engaged for operational planning), forcing consensus creates political conflict. (3) Metric accountability—if single definition enforced, one function's metrics deteriorate (e.g., if billing definition chosen, CRM account counts decline making sales territories appear under-performing, quota achievement rates decline). (4) Historical comparability—if definition changed to enforce consistency, historical customer metrics restated, trend analysis disrupted, investor questions why counts changed. Current state = tolerance allows each function to optimize on own definition without enterprise reconciliation forcing political/technical costs.
evidence_sources: Stage 7.1 customer count/churn contested domain parallel truths
Stage 7.2 customer identity transformation CRM N ≠ M ≠ K
Stage 4.1 no operating committee to reconcile cross-functional disputes
Stage 7.1 H7.1-B governance void no data reconciliation infrastructure

error_tolerance_map.data_domain: Support ticketing data completeness—escalations and resolutions outside system of record
common_error_types: Executive escalation resolution unrecorded—customers escalate to CEO/executives directly (BBB: 'cannot reach CEO'), resolution occurs outside ticketing system, ticket remains 'open' or 'unresolved' in system of record

Manual intervention not logged—when executives resolve customer issues via direct contact, ticketing system not updated with resolution, SLA metrics unchanged (resolution time doesn't include executive intervention time), customer satisfaction improvement not captured

Escalation paths incomplete—systematic escalation mechanism absent (Stage 4.1 coordination gaps), customers resort to external platforms (BBB, social media) to reach executives, escalation frequency/severity not tracked systematically

Ticket classification errors—operations controls classification (Stage 7.2 authority controls transformation), severity/impact understated to preserve performance metrics, customer-perceived critical classified as moderate by operations
error_tolerance_map.tolerance_threshold: TOLERANCE WHILE EXECUTIVE BANDWIDTH AVAILABLE: Errors tolerated as long as CEO/executives can manually handle escalations within available bandwidth. THRESHOLD APPROACHING: Three CEOs in three years (Stage 4.5) indicates CEO bandwidth exhausted—if escalation volume increases or CEO transitions continue, manual escalation handling breaks. No explicit threshold documented—tolerance implicit through CEO willingness to absorb escalation workload. Tolerance duration: Ongoing since executive escalation path established (years), continues until executive bandwidth exceeded or regulatory/audit scrutiny questions ticketing data completeness.
error_tolerance_map.who_accepts_the_risk: RISK DISTRIBUTION: Support operations benefits from ticketing incompleteness—SLA compliance metrics preserved (unrecorded escalations don't degrade SLA performance), resolution rates appear higher than reality (executive resolutions not counted as support failures). CEO/executives absorb escalation workload—manual resolution outside system consumes CEO bandwidth (Stage 4.2 CEO bottleneck worsened by escalation handling). Customers absorb escalation cost—must persist to external platforms (BBB, direct CEO contact) to achieve resolution, initial support ticket resolution inadequate. Finance/investor relations absorb brand risk—BBB complaints visible externally ('consistently worse' Trustpilot 2024), 'Fanatical Support' brand claims contradicted by escalation necessity.
error_tolerance_map.business_or_regulatory_consequence: BUSINESS CONSEQUENCES: Support performance metrics overstated (SLA compliance high but customer satisfaction declining, measurement theater Stage 7.2 Pattern 1), customer churn risk invisible (escalation patterns not analyzed systematically, churn precursors undetected), executive bandwidth consumed by escalation handling (CEO bottleneck Stage 4.2 worsened, strategic decision-making capacity reduced). Brand-reality gap—'Fanatical Support' marketing claims contradicted by BBB/Trustpilot complaints requiring external escalation. REGULATORY CONSEQUENCES: Minimal direct regulatory risk, but if support data used for SOC 2 or ISO certification claims (incident response, customer service quality), auditor may question data completeness discovering escalations untracked.
error_tolerance_map.touch_test_what_breaks_if_zero_tolerance: Zero tolerance = all escalations recorded in ticketing system, executive resolutions logged with resolution time, escalation paths systematized. BREAKS: (1) Support performance metrics—if escalations recorded, SLA compliance declines (resolution time includes executive intervention), resolution rates decline (tickets previously 'closed' in system but unresolved by customer now marked escalated), support metrics deteriorate. (2) Executive workload visibility—if escalations systematically tracked, CEO/executive escalation handling time quantified revealing bottleneck severity (Stage 4.2 bottleneck may appear worse than currently visible). (3) Compensation impact—if support metrics decline due to complete recording, support personnel/management compensation affected (metrics-based incentives Stage 4.4). (4) Escalation volume growth—if systematic escalation path established (not just ad-hoc CEO contact), escalation volume may increase (customers currently giving up without escalation may escalate if path clear), overwhelming available escalation handling capacity. Current tolerance = preserves support metric optics while externalizing customer satisfaction/escalation cost to executives and customers.
evidence_sources: BBB complaints customers 'cannot reach CEO', unresolved tickets
Stage 7.2 manual override pattern executive resolution outside system
Stage 7.1 support satisfaction vs SLA contested domain
Stage 4.1 escalation paths absent systematic coordination

error_tolerance_map.data_domain: Customer satisfaction measurement—internal data absence or suppression vs external platform truth
common_error_types: Internal satisfaction data not collected systematically—no enterprise NPS, CSAT, or satisfaction survey program visible (Stage 7.1 uncertainty: 'whether satisfaction data collected and suppressed or not collected')
Activity-outcome conflation—'SLA met' (controllable activity) reported as proxy for 'customer satisfied' (uncontrollable outcome) without outcome validation (Stage 7.2 Pattern 1)
External platform truth divergence—Trustpilot 'consistently worse' 2024, Gartner peer reviews, BBB complaints provide satisfaction reality contradicting internal SLA compliance claims
Measurement theater—internal satisfaction measurement absent or ignored while 'Fanatical Support' brand claims made, brand-reality gap unquantified internally
error_tolerance_map.tolerance_threshold: TOLERANCE INDEFINITE WHILE CHURN MANAGEABLE: Satisfaction measurement gap tolerated as long as customer churn doesn't trigger financial crisis. IMPLICIT THRESHOLD: If churn accelerates materially threatening revenue stability or if major customer publicly criticizes service triggering investor scrutiny, satisfaction measurement may be forced. No explicit threshold—satisfaction truth externalized to customers and external platforms, internal measurement avoided. Tolerance duration: Years (satisfaction measurement gap structural not episodic, persists across CEO transitions).
error_tolerance_map.who_accepts_the_risk: RISK DISTRIBUTION: Support operations benefits from measurement gap—optimization on controllable SLA metrics (response time, ticket closure) not uncontrollable satisfaction outcomes, easier performance management without satisfaction accountability. Marketing/brand management accepts brand risk—'Fanatical Support' claims made without internal validation, brand-reality gap discovered through external platforms post-campaign. Customer success/account management absorb churn risk—lack of satisfaction leading indicators means churn discovered reactively (customer cancels) not proactively (satisfaction declining, intervention possible). CEO/Board accept strategic blindness—customer experience deteriorating invisible internally (Trustpilot 'consistently worse' 2024), strategic decisions on service quality uninformed by systematic satisfaction data.
error_tolerance_map.business_or_regulatory_consequence: BUSINESS CONSEQUENCES MATERIAL: Churn risk invisible until customer cancels (no early warning from satisfaction trends), customer lifetime value calculations unreliable (satisfaction trajectory unknown), service quality investment misallocated (internal SLA optimization continues while satisfaction declines, investment doesn't target actual customer pain points). Brand damage—'Fanatical Support' claims increasingly contradicted by external platforms, marketing ROI negative if brand promises undeliverable. Competitive disadvantage—competitors with systematic satisfaction measurement can target Rackspace weaknesses invisible to Rackspace itself. REGULATORY CONSEQUENCES: Minimal, satisfaction data not regulated. But if brand claims deemed misleading (FTC advertising standards), gap between 'Fanatical Support' marketing and BBB/Trustpilot reality could trigger scrutiny.
error_tolerance_map.touch_test_what_breaks_if_zero_tolerance: Zero tolerance = systematic internal satisfaction measurement required, NPS/CSAT surveys enterprise-wide, satisfaction metrics reported alongside SLA metrics, brand claims validated against measurement. BREAKS: (1) Support accountability—if satisfaction measured and declining while SLA stable, support performance narrative contradicted, resource increase required or SLA targets must be abandoned as insufficient for satisfaction. (2) Activity-outcome misalignment visible—systematic measurement reveals SLA compliance doesn't predict satisfaction (Stage 7.2 activity-outcome drift), forces reconsideration of what support optimizes for, potentially requiring service model redesign. (3) Brand claims unsustainable—if satisfaction measured and shows 'consistently worse' trajectory, 'Fanatical Support' brand claims must be retired or qualified, marketing strategy requires revision. (4) Executive escalation frequency quantified—satisfaction surveys may reveal escalation patterns (customers dissatisfied with initial support, forced to escalate), escalation handling burden quantified (Stage 4.2 CEO bottleneck). Current tolerance = preserves support metric optimization and brand claim continuity while externalizing satisfaction truth discovery to customers and external platforms.
evidence_sources: Stage 7.1 uncertainty satisfaction measurement practices unknown
Stage 7.2 support performance transformation SLA-satisfaction drift
Stage 4.4 support incentive on SLA not satisfaction

error_tolerance_map.data_domain: Incident frequency and recurrence tracking—prevention gaps masked by response capability focus
common_error_types: Incident frequency not systematically measured—operations reports MTTD (mean time to detect) and MTTR (mean time to respond) capability metrics, but incident count over time and recurrence patterns not tracked systematically (Stage 7.2 incident transformation)

Root cause analysis not followed by prevention validation—root cause documented post-incident (Stage 7.2 temporal drift: T0 incident, T1 root cause analysis), prevention actions identified, but prevention execution not validated before recurrence (T2 recurrence occurs before prevention complete)

Capability-frequency conflation—strong response capability (MTTD/MTTR) reported as 'operational stability' without frequency measurement, recurrence contradicts stability claims (ransomware multi-month, zero-day Sept 2024)

Severity classification understated—operations controls classification (Stage 7.2 authority controls transformation Pattern 4), customer-perceived critical classified as moderate to preserve performance metrics
error_tolerance_map.tolerance_threshold: TOLERANCE UNTIL REGULATORY/CUSTOMER VISIBILITY: Incident recurrence tolerated as long as incidents don't trigger regulatory reporting (FedRAMP, HIPAA breach notification), major customer public complaint, or auditor questioning. THRESHOLD EXAMPLES: Ransomware multi-month indicates tolerance for recurrence until remediation complete (months), zero-day Sept 2024 indicates tolerance for vulnerability exploitation until patch available. No explicit recurrence tolerance policy—tolerance implicit through operations focus on response not prevention. Tolerance duration: Weeks to months per incident type (ransomware multi-month, zero-day exploit window until patch).
error_tolerance_map.who_accepts_the_risk: RISK DISTRIBUTION: Operations benefits from frequency measurement gap—response capability optimization (MTTD/MTTR controllable) without prevention accountability (recurrence frequency uncontrollable, measurement would reveal prevention gaps). Operations reports 'strong incident response' without frequency context. Customers absorb recurrence risk—service disruptions repeat, customers experience 'operational stability' claims contradicted by recurring incidents. Compliance/legal accept regulatory risk—if incident recurrence triggers breach notification requirements (FedRAMP, HIPAA), compliance team manages regulatory response reactively, prevention gap upstream in operations invisible until breach. CEO/Board accept strategic blindness—incident recurrence patterns not analyzed systematically (Stage 7.1 incident domain truth fragmented), strategic decisions on infrastructure investment or vendor dependency (Stage 6) uninformed by recurrence data.
error_tolerance_map.business_or_regulatory_consequence: BUSINESS CONSEQUENCES: Customer churn risk from recurring incidents (reliability reputation damaged), SLA penalty exposure if incidents breach availability/performance commitments, competitive disadvantage if competitors prevent incidents Rackspace only responds to. Operational costs—repeated incident response more expensive than prevention investment, but prevention ROI invisible without frequency tracking. REGULATORY CONSEQUENCES MATERIAL: FedRAP authorization revoked if incident recurrence pattern discovered during audit and deemed preventable (government customers lost). HIPAA breach notification required if PHI exposed in recurring incidents (fines, reputation damage). PCI DSS compliance questioned if security incidents recurring in payment processing environments (merchant account risk). Regulatory risk proportional to recurrence frequency—single incidents tolerable, recurring patterns trigger scrutiny.
error_tolerance_map.touch_test_what_breaks_if_zero_tolerance: Zero tolerance = incident frequency and recurrence systematically measured, prevention validation required before incident type closed, recurrence treated as prevention failure not acceptable operational reality. BREAKS: (1) Operations performance metrics—if recurrence tracked, 'operational stability' claims contradicted by frequency data, response capability strength insufficient for stability claim without prevention. (2) Prevention investment required—if recurrence measured and deemed intolerable, prevention investment (infrastructure redundancy, vendor diversification Stage 6, security tooling) required, capital expenditure increases ($1.3B debt Stage 5 constrains investment capacity). (3) Accountability shift—if recurrence tracked, operations accountable for prevention not just response, incentive structure must change (Stage 4.4 operations incentive on response capability not frequency reduction), potentially requiring resource reallocation or headcount increase. (4) Vendor dependency visible—if recurrence analysis shows vendor-driven incidents (Stage 6 vendor dependencies), vendor renegotiation or replacement required (switching costs high, multi-jurisdictional contracts Stage 4.3 complicate vendor changes). Current tolerance = preserves operations response capability narrative while externalizing recurrence cost to customers and compliance team.
evidence_sources: Stage 7.2 incident transformation MTTD/MTTR capability not frequency

error_tolerance_map.data_domain: Multi-jurisdictional operational data aggregation—variance erasure creates false fungibility
common_error_types: Jurisdiction-specific capacity constraints erased in enterprise aggregation—FedRAMP, UK, HIPAA, China capacities isolated and non-fungible (Stage 6 regulatory/vendor constraints), but enterprise utilization/capacity metrics aggregated as if fungible

Coordination multiplier invisible—5-6x coordination overhead for multi-jurisdictional operations (Stage 4.3) not reflected in aggregated metrics, enterprise efficiency appears higher than jurisdiction-level reality

Workload mobility overstated—enterprise aggregate metrics imply workload can move across jurisdictions, but regulatory/contractual constraints prevent mobility (FedRAMP workloads cannot move to non-FedRAMP infrastructure), aggregate metrics mislead on available capacity

Performance metric aggregation—jurisdiction-specific SLA, incident response, availability aggregated into enterprise averages erasing variance (high-performing jurisdiction averages with low-performing, variance invisible)
error_tolerance_map.tolerance_threshold: TOLERANCE WHILE VARIANCE DOESN'T CAUSE EXECUTION FAILURE: Aggregation errors tolerated as long as investment decisions based on aggregated metrics don't fail due to jurisdiction constraints. IMPLICIT THRESHOLD: If expansion investment fails because assumed fungible capacity actually jurisdiction-locked, or if customer deployment fails because enterprise utilization suggested capacity available but jurisdiction-specific utilization at 100%, tolerance may end. No explicit threshold—aggregation methodology inherited, not actively managed. Tolerance duration: Years (aggregation methodology established with reporting systems, unchanged across CEO transitions, no governance initiative to disaggregate visible).
error_tolerance_map.who_accepts_the_risk: RISK DISTRIBUTION: Finance benefits from aggregation simplicity—investor communications simpler with enterprise aggregates than jurisdiction-specific breakouts, variance disclosure avoided, operational complexity hidden. Finance controls aggregation methodology (Stage 7.1 epistemic power), optimizes for investor communication ease not operational fidelity. Operations absorbs misallocation cost—investment decisions based on aggregated metrics misallocate resources (expansion in low-utilization jurisdiction doesn't relieve high-utilization jurisdiction if capacity non-fungible), operations executes on misallocated resources causing delivery failures. CEO/Board accept strategic blindness—multi-jurisdictional complexity (5-6x multiplier Stage 4.3) invisible in aggregated metrics, strategic decisions on capacity expansion, M&A integration, vendor consolidation (Stage 6) uninformed by jurisdiction-specific operational reality. Customers absorb deployment failures—when customer workload cannot deploy due to jurisdiction-specific constraint invisible in enterprise metrics, customer experiences delay or service unavailability.
error_tolerance_map.business_or_regulatory_consequence: BUSINESS CONSEQUENCES: Capital misallocation—investment in capacity expansion based on aggregate utilization may expand wrong jurisdiction (low-utilization jurisdiction expanded while high-utilization jurisdiction remains constrained). Delivery failures—customer commitments made based on enterprise capacity availability fail when jurisdiction-specific capacity unavailable (contract SLA breach risk). M&A integration complexity underestimated—acquirer assumes enterprise aggregates represent fungible integrated operations, discovers jurisdiction isolation post-close requiring integration redesign. Competitive disadvantage—competitors with jurisdiction-specific operational visibility can target capacity/price more accurately. REGULATORY CONSEQUENCES: If FedRAMP, HIPAA, PCI compliance claimed enterprise-wide but jurisdiction-specific gaps exist (aggregation masks compliance variance), regulatory audit discovers misrepresentation risk. If aggregated metrics used in material investor communications (capacity, utilization, performance) and later discovered materially inaccurate due to variance erasure, guidance credibility damaged.
error_tolerance_map.touch_test_what_breaks_if_zero_tolerance: Zero tolerance = jurisdiction-specific operational metrics reported alongside enterprise aggregates, variance disclosed, coordination multiplier quantified, capacity fungibility limitations explicit. BREAKS: (1) Investor communication complexity—jurisdiction-specific reporting reveals operational heterogeneity, 5-6x coordination overhead visible, enterprise efficiency appears lower than current aggregate-based narrative, investor perception of operational maturity damaged. (2) Aggregation methodology contested—if disaggregated, functions dispute which aggregation valid (simple sum, weighted average, consolidated with eliminations Stage 7.2 uncertainty), cross-functional conflict over methodology emerges. (3) Performance accountability—if jurisdiction-specific performance visible, underperforming jurisdictions identified requiring intervention (management changes, investment, or divestiture), but CEO bandwidth insufficient for jurisdiction-level management (Stage 4.2 CEO bottleneck). (4) Strategic decisions complicated—if variance visible, capacity expansion, vendor negotiation, M&A integration require jurisdiction-specific analysis (more complex, time-consuming, resource-intensive than aggregate-based decisions). Current tolerance = preserves investor communication simplicity and operational narrative while externalizing misallocation and delivery failure costs to operations and customers.
evidence_sources: Stage 7.2 multi-jurisdictional transformation Flow 5 variance erasure

synthesis_notes: Six material data domains with chronic error tolerance identified: deal profitability (13-15% overstatement tolerated until Q4 2024 reactive intervention), customer counts (parallel definitions tolerated indefinitely), support ticketing completeness (escalations unrecorded tolerated while CEO bandwidth available), satisfaction measurement (gap tolerated indefinitely, truth externalized), incident frequency (recurrence tolerated until regulatory/customer crisis), multi-jurisdictional aggregation (variance erasure tolerated until execution failure). Error tolerance NOT UNIFORM—tolerance varies by: (1) Externalization feasibility (deal profitability risk absorbed by delivery/finance until CEO intervenes, satisfaction risk externalized to customers/external platforms indefinitely), (2) Measurement theater value (support SLA optimization easier without satisfaction accountability, operations response optimization easier without frequency tracking), (3) Political cost of enforcement (zero tolerance on CRM profitability breaks sales model, zero tolerance on aggregation complexity damages investor narrative). Tolerance thresholds predominantly IMPLICIT not explicit—no documented error tolerance policies, thresholds discovered reactively through crisis (margin erosion -13%/-3% triggered walk away policy, CEO bandwidth exhaustion evident through three CEOs three years). Risk acceptance DISTRIBUTED not centralized—function causing error (sales CRM optimism) externalizes cost to other functions (delivery margin absorption), function controlling transformation (finance aggregation) externalizes execution risk to operations. Touch tests reveal zero tolerance enforcement BREAKS CURRENT OPERATING MODEL systematically—sales cycle velocity, support metric optics, operations response narrative, investor communication simplicity all dependent on error tolerance. Error tolerance functions as IMPLICIT ORGANIZATIONAL POLICY enabling local optimization while externalizing systemic costs.
